Queshi Bridge | Generated by AI

Home 2025.10

The Queshi Bridge in Shantou, China, has a story rooted in the city’s development as a key port and its evolving infrastructure needs. Spanning the Rongjiang River, the bridge connects downtown Shantou to the Queshi area, historically significant for its foreign presence after Shantou became a treaty port in 1860 following the Treaty of Tientsin. While the bridge itself doesn’t have a singular dramatic origin tale, its history reflects Shantou’s growth and the practical demands of linking its urban core with outlying regions like Queshi, once home to American and British consulates.

The first notable bridge in this context was built in 1934, a pontoon bridge made of boats lashed together, reflecting the resourcefulness of the time amid limited engineering capacity. This floating structure served as a critical link until 1958, when Typhoon Ella struck, severely damaging it with storm surges and flooding—a reminder of Shantou’s vulnerability to natural disasters due to its coastal location. The destruction prompted a rethink, and by 1962, a more permanent reinforced concrete bridge was constructed, marking a shift to modern infrastructure.

This concrete iteration stood until the late 1980s when rapid urban expansion and increased traffic demanded something sturdier. Construction on the current Queshi Bridge began in 1988 and finished in 1992. Designed as a prestressed concrete cable-stayed bridge, it stretches 618 meters long and 30 meters wide, with a distinctive 148-meter-high tower resembling an “A” shape—a nod to both functionality and aesthetic ambition. At the time, it was a point of pride for Shantou, reflecting the city’s economic rise during China’s reform era.

Beyond its engineering, the bridge carries cultural weight. It’s tied to the memory of Shantou’s overseas Chinese community, many of whom funded infrastructure projects in their hometowns—though specific donor records for Queshi Bridge are unclear. Today, it’s more than a crossing; it’s a scenic spot, with views of the Rongjiang River and the lush Queshi Park, blending utility with the city’s push for tourism. Its story is less about a single event and more about Shantou’s steady transformation from a treaty port to a modern hub, with the bridge as a quiet witness to that change.
